home.heroSubtitle: Explore over {{count}} monuments, historic buildings and archaeological sites in Spain, Italy, France and Portugal.
home.ctaText: Create your account to explore all monuments, save favorites and access the interactive map
home.feature1Desc: Filter by country, region, category, style and more among thousands of monuments
home.feature2Desc: Create optimized routes between monuments and export them to GPS or Google Maps
home.feature3Desc: Photos, Wikipedia descriptions, exact locations and historical data
home.feature4Desc: Available in 8 languages for explorers across Europe
home.testimonial1: The best tool I've found for planning cultural visits. The route planner is incredible.
home.testimonial2: As a history teacher, I use this platform to prepare field trips with my students. Essential.
home.testimonial3: I discovered monuments in my own region that I didn't know existed. The information is very complete.
home.pricingPreviewDesc: From free to premium, find the perfect plan for your way of exploring heritage

pricing.title: Plans & Pricing
pricing.subtitle: Choose the plan that best fits your way of exploring heritage

plans.freeDesc: Discover European heritage at no cost
plans.basicDesc: For those who plan cultural visits
plans.premiumDesc: The complete experience for heritage enthusiasts

pricing.faq1Q: Can I change my plan anytime?
pricing.faq1A: Yes, you can upgrade or downgrade anytime. Changes apply immediately and the cost is prorated.
pricing.faq2A: The Explorer plan is always free. Paid plans include a 14-day free trial with no commitment.
pricing.faq3Q: What payment methods do you accept?
pricing.faq3A: We accept credit/debit cards (Visa, Mastercard, Amex) and PayPal. All payments are secure.
pricing.faq4A: Yes, no commitment. You can cancel anytime and keep access until the end of your billing period.
pricing.trialDesc: Access all premium features with no commitment. No credit card required.

premium.title: Premium Feature
premium.description: Unlock this feature with a paid plan

cookies.message: We use cookies to improve your experience. By continuing to browse, you accept our cookie policy.

curatedRoutes.title: Cultural routes
curatedRoutes.subtitle: Discover 35 thematic itineraries through the historical heritage of Spain, France and Portugal
curatedRoutes.searchPlaceholder: Search routes by name, monument or period...
curatedRoutes.noResults: No routes found with those filters
curatedRoutes.noMonumentsFound: No monuments found for this route
curatedRoutes.route1Desc: The Camino Frances is a map of European Romanesque development, with churches and monasteries from the 11th-13th centuries stretching from Jaca to Santiago de Compostela.
curatedRoutes.route2Desc: A group of 9 UNESCO Lombard Romanesque churches from the 11th-12th centuries in a small Pyrenean valley. Sant Climent de Taull houses the famous Christ Pantocrator.
curatedRoutes.route3Desc: The greatest concentration of Romanesque monuments in Europe, with over 90 catalogued buildings in the province of Palencia.
curatedRoutes.route4Desc: From Spain's first Romanesque cathedral in Jaca to the rock-sheltered monastery of San Juan de la Pena, cradle of the Kingdom of Aragon.
curatedRoutes.route5Desc: A Jacobean route along the northern coast with examples of coastal Romanesque from the 12th-13th centuries between the Basque Country, Cantabria and Asturias.
curatedRoutes.route6Desc: Rural Romanesque churches of great architectural value in the border districts of Soria, with gems such as Santo Domingo and San Juan de Rabanera.
curatedRoutes.route7Desc: Between the 12th and 15th centuries, France raised over 80 Gothic cathedrals. Chartres, Amiens, Reims and Notre-Dame de Paris are the masterpieces of the style.
curatedRoutes.route8Desc: Levantine Gothic is characterised by the unification of space, with the Silk Exchange as a UNESCO masterpiece and the emblematic Torres de Serranos.
curatedRoutes.route9Desc: A circuit through three of Spain's most important Gothic cathedrals: Burgos (UNESCO), Leon (stained glass) and Palencia.
curatedRoutes.route10Desc: UNESCO Mudejar architecture, a unique fusion of Christian and Islamic elements. Includes the Aljaferia, the Towers of Teruel and the Collegiate Church of Calatayud.
curatedRoutes.route11Desc: UNESCO Renaissance monumental ensembles from 2003, the work of Andres de Vandelvira, which influenced the architecture of Latin America.
curatedRoutes.route12Desc: Salamanca's Plaza Mayor is a European Baroque civil masterpiece. The city owes much of its UNESCO status to the Churriguera family.
curatedRoutes.route13Desc: A 105 km route connecting three 12th-century Cistercian monasteries in Catalonia. Poblet is the largest inhabited monastery in Europe.
curatedRoutes.route14Desc: Three World Heritage monasteries: Alcobaca (Cistercian), Batalha (Battle of Aljubarrota) and Tomar (Templar with the Charola).
curatedRoutes.route15Desc: UNESCO Mont Saint-Michel, a medieval abbey on a granite islet, leads this route of Norman abbeys built between the 11th and 16th centuries.
curatedRoutes.route16Desc: More than 300 Renaissance chateaux along the Loire. Chambord, Chenonceau and Amboise are the jewels of the region.
curatedRoutes.route17Desc: Medieval 'eagle's nest' castles in the mountains of southern France, linked to the Cathar heresy and the Albigensian Crusade.
curatedRoutes.route18Desc: Strategic defensive fortresses on the Castilian plateau, from the Alcazar of Segovia to the Castle of Penafiel.
curatedRoutes.route19Desc: A route of Templar castles from Ponferrada to Tomar, built to protect the Christian kingdoms during the Reconquista.
curatedRoutes.route20Desc: The legacy of the Nasrid kingdom with the UNESCO Alhambra at its summit, together with alcazabas and watchtowers of Granada, Almeria and Malaga.
curatedRoutes.route21Desc: The taifas of Zaragoza, Toledo and Badajoz were Islamic powers after the fall of the Caliphate, with palaces such as the UNESCO Aljaferia.
curatedRoutes.route22Desc: UNESCO Asturian pre-Romanesque art from the 9th-10th centuries. Santa Maria del Naranco and San Miguel de Lillo are unique works in Europe.
curatedRoutes.route23Desc: Mozarabic churches of Christians who kept their faith under Arab rule, from Toledo to Santiago de Penalba in El Bierzo.
curatedRoutes.route24Desc: A 700 km Roman road from UNESCO Merida to Astorga, completed under Augustus, Trajan and Hadrian.
curatedRoutes.route25Desc: The largest megalithic complex on the Iberian Peninsula, with over 800 dolmens in the Alentejo and the Cromlech of Almendres.
curatedRoutes.route26Desc: UNESCO Archaeological Site since 2016 with the dolmens of Menga, Viera and El Romeral, among the largest in Europe.
curatedRoutes.route27Desc: UNESCO Altamira and 17 more caves with Palaeolithic cave art dating from 35,000-11,000 years ago along the Cantabrian coast.
curatedRoutes.route28Desc: 12 UNESCO fortified sites by military engineer Vauban for Louis XIV, prime examples of classical star fortification.
curatedRoutes.route29Desc: Fortresses and defensive towers over a thousand years old in strategic locations near the ancient borders of Catalonia.
curatedRoutes.route30Desc: The most-travelled Jacobean route, spanning over 800 km from the Pyrenees to Santiago, described in the Codex Calixtinus of 1135.
curatedRoutes.route31Desc: The oldest of the Ways, followed by Alfonso II the Chaste in the 9th century between Oviedo and Santiago, with pre-Romanesque heritage.
curatedRoutes.route32Desc: A Jacobean route from Lisbon or Porto to Santiago, crossing into Galicia via Valenca with cathedrals and Portuguese heritage.
curatedRoutes.route33Desc: Barcelona is home to 5 UNESCO Modernist buildings by Gaudi. Sagrada Familia, Park Guell and Casa Batllo lead this unique route.
curatedRoutes.route34Desc: The seasonal palaces of the crown: UNESCO Aranjuez (spring), La Granja (summer), UNESCO El Escorial (autumn) and Madrid (winter).
curatedRoutes.route35Desc: UNESCO Talavera ceramics and the Basilica del Prado, the 'Sistine Chapel of Toledo ceramics', with active artisan workshops.
